title: Indexed Database API
text:
The Indexed Database API (commonly referred to as IndexedDB) is a <a href="JavaScript">JavaScript</a> <a href="application%20programming%20interface">application programming interface</a> (API) provided by <a href="web%20browser">web browser</a>s for managing a <a href="NoSQL">NoSQL</a> <a href="database">database</a> of <a href="JSON">JSON</a> objects. It is a standard maintained by the <a href="World%20Wide%20Web%20Consortium">World Wide Web Consortium</a> (W3C).
As an alternative to the <a href="Web%20storage">Web storage</a> standard, IndexedDB can provide more storage capacity. Web storage has <a href="Web_storage%23Storage_size">fixed limits</a> per <a href="website">website</a>, but IndexedDB limits are "usually quite large, if they exist at all".
<a href="Use%20case">Use case</a>s for IndexedDB include caching <a href="web%20application">web application</a> data for <a href="offline">offline</a> availability. Some browser modules, such as <a href="Web%20development%20tools">devtools</a> or <a href="browser%20extension">extensions</a>, may also use it for storage.
History.
Support for IndexedDB was added to <a href="Firefox">Firefox</a> version 4, <a href="Google%20Chrome">Google Chrome</a> version 11, <a href="Internet%20Explorer">Internet Explorer</a> version 10, <a href="Safari%20%28web%20browser%29">Safari</a> version 8, and <a href="Microsoft%20Edge">Microsoft Edge</a> version 12.
<a href="Web%20SQL%20Database">Web SQL Database</a> was a prior API developed by <a href="Apple%20Inc.">Apple</a>. But Firefox refused to add support for it and argued against it becoming a standard because it would codify the quirks of <a href="SQLite">SQLite</a>. It was thus <a href="deprecation">deprecated</a> in favor of IndexedDB.
"IndexedDB 1.0" became a <a href="World%20Wide%20Web%20Consortium%23W3C%20recommendation%20%28REC%29">W3C Recommendation</a> on January 8th, 2015. "IndexedDB 2.0" became a W3C Recommendation on January 30th, 2018. "IndexedDB 3.0" is currently a <a href="World%20Wide%20Web%20Consortium%23Working%20draft%20%28WD%29">First Public Working Draft</a>.
